description: Uncertain; compare shinney, shinty. Tentatively suggested to be a compound of the Irish words seinn (“music”) and tí (“house”).

nouns.description: shindy (countable and uncountable, plural shindies or shindys)

examples: She and Eileen are giving a shindy for Gladys—that's Gerald's new acquisition, you know. So if you don't mind butting into a baby-show we'll run down.

entries.meaning: (slang) An uproar or disturbance; a spree; a row; a riot.
examples: I always do sit with my hands in my pockets except when I am in the company of my sisters, my cousins, or my aunts; and they kick up such a shindy—I should say expostulate so eloquently upon the subject—that I have to give in and take them out—my hands I mean.

[…]  what is even more disgusting still, I have seen children playing at "shindy" in a Churchyard, a skull used as a substitute for a ball, and large fragments of leg or arm-bones in the place of sticks.

entries.meaning: (US, dialect, dated) A fancy or liking.
examples: "Father took a wonderful shindy to her, for even old men can't help liking beauty.  […] "
